Award.AwardTitle: BRIGE: Understanding the generalization of treadmill-assisted motor learning for the rehabilitation of gait after stroke

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical description:

A major issue in rehabilitation robotics is the fact that motor learning acquired on devices like robots and treadmills is highly specific and does not improve patients? movements during ?real life? situations. How to manipulate the generalization of robotic-assisted motor learning? This is an interesting challenge for engineers and an important question for clinicians. To understand the poor transfer of robotic-assisted motor learning to natural movements the PI proposes to investigate what the device changes and how to manipulate it. This will be done though a novel application of factorization analyses that are conventionally used for image processing. The PI specifically proposes to quantify changes in muscle activity post-stroke when subjects learn a new walking pattern on a split-belt treadmill (research objective 1). This treadmill has two belts that can move at different speeds to create novel environmental conditions and induced motor learning. Then, the PI will identify what aspects of the muscle activation patterns learned on the split-belt treadmill generalize to natural walking, and whether the acquisition phase on the split-belt treadmill can be manipulated to increase the generalization effects (research objective 2). Anticipated results will advance the current knowledge of mechanisms available to post-stroke subjects for changing their aberrant muscle activity and the generalization of those changes to natural walking.

Broader significance and importance:

The potential benefit of this proposal is to advance our knowledge of the ?rules? for motor adaptation and generalization in the intact and post-stroke human motor system. This should allow us to understand how to use technology to train individuals, and ultimately rehabilitate their walking and movement control in general. The risks to the subjects participating in the proposed studies are minimal, and the benefit to society could be substantial. According to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention there are nearly 650,000 post-stroke survivors every year, making stroke the leading cause for long-term disability in the United States. This proposal has the potential to help develop effective and efficient rehabilitation treatments for post-stroke survivors. This would directly benefit patients by improving their movements and reducing their medical care costs, which impose a substantial economic burden to the individuals and society.

Broadening participation of underrepresented groups in engineering:

Importantly, the PI will use the research objectives in this proposal as means to expose students from underrepresented groups in engineering to solve real rehabilitation needs (educational objective 1), engage them in research that applies engineering tools to inform the field of physical rehabilitation (educational objective 2), and prepare them to continue graduate education (educational objective 3). These educational objectives will be fulfilled through the Pre-PhD Research Experience at Pitt (PREP) program developed by the PI. To implement her program the PI will recruit, mentor, and prepare undergraduate students from Hispanic serving Universities to pursue advanced degrees. She will also incorporate her research activities with the program INVESTING NOW, which prepares high schools students (89% from minority groups and 47% females) mostly from underrepresented groups in engineering to pursue engineering degrees. In sum, the PI?s educational objectives will prepare students from underrepresented groups in engineering to pursue advanced degrees, which will in turn redefine the boundaries of education and professional development available to underrepresented groups in science and engineering.

This research has been funded through the Broadening Participation Research Initiation Grants in Engineering solicitation, which is part of the Broadening Participation in Engineering Program of the Engineering Education and Centers Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I. Overview

 

A major issue in rehabilitation robotics is the fact that motor learning acquired on devices like robots and treadmills is highly specific and does not improve patients’ movements during ‘real life’ situations. How to manipulate the generalization of robotic-assisted motor learning? This is an interesting challenge for engineers and an important question for clinicians.  To understand the poor transfer of robotic-assisted motor learning to natural movements the PI investigated the plasticity in muscle coordination in unimpaired and post-stroke patients. This was done ewhen subjects learned a new walking pattern on a split-belt treadmill, which has two belts that can move at different speeds to create novel environmental conditions and induce motor learning. Our results advanced the current knowledge of mechanisms available to post-stroke subjects for changing their aberrant muscle activity and the generalization of those changes to natural walking.

 

The following was accomplished during our two years of funding:

1)     Performed locomotor learning experiments on 32 patients

2)     Implemented nonparametric statistical tests to analyze post-stroke data, which is largely heterogeneous.

3)     Designed novel approach to distinguish muscle co-activation that is task-dependent vs. muscle co-activation due to common neural drive

4)     Related muscle activity features with motor dysfunction as quantified by Fugl-Meyer scores.

5)     Performed unprecedented state-space analysis on electromyographic recordings to identify the linear dynamics in the adaptation of muscle activity.

 

II. Intellectual merit.

 As part of the PI's goal to understand the poor transfer of robotic-assisted motor learning to natural movements the PI used this support to study what aspects of muscle activity are changed by the split-belt treadmill changes and how to manipulate them. This was done done through a novel application of factorization techniques conventionally used for image processing to analyze muscle activity across multiple muscles. The PIs team also used analytical tools conventionally used for modeling linear dynamic systems. The PI quantified changes in muscle activity and kinematics when stroke patients learned a new walking pattern on the split-belt treadmill. To this end the PI tested and analyzed the data of 32 patients post-stroke and 16 control subjects. Figure 1 shows results of the statistical analysis of muscle activity in 16 control and 16 post-stroke patients. These grids indicate differences in mean activity for each muscle during the gait cycles of baseline vs. split-belt walking. Red colors indicate an increase in muscle activity compared to baseline and blue colors indicate a decrease in activity compared to baseline. Significant changes are illustrated with dots and outlined areas indicate opposite changes across legs (i.e., increase in one leg matched by decrease in the other one). Note that, unlike controls, patients do not increase the muscle activity of hamstring and quadriceps muscles on the paretic side. This poor recruitment could be done to their neural lesions.   

Importantly, split-belt walking can be modified to induce larger changes in proximal muscles post-stroke. Figure 2A shows the kinematic (Figure 2A) data of uphill vs. flat split-belt walking. Note that patients adapt more their gait and have larger after-effects in the uphill-split condition. Accordingly, the changes in EMG activity in uphill-split walking compared to uphill baseline walking are more substantial than those observed during flat-split walking (Figure 1).

 We also implemented a novel analytical approach to identify muscle synergies (i.e., muscles activated by common neural drive). We performed this analysis to identify covariation across muscles during their periodic activation over the gait cycle (Figure 3A) or during trial-to-trial variations (Figure 3B). This analysis enabled us to identify intralimb and interlimb covariations in muscle activity that are task-dependent (Figure 3A). On the other hand, the trial-to-trial analysis mostly revels covariations across anatomical muscle groups, which might result from reflex responses caused by common mechanical stretch.   

Lastly, we performed a state space analysis to assess linear aspects in the evolution of muscle activity as subjects adapt their gait to the novel environment (Figure 4). This unprecedented analysis shows that the adaptation of muscle activity can be reproduced by a time-invariant-linear system that has two hidden states: one that adapts slowly (orange line), and one that adapts fast (blue line). Importantly, our results also show that some aspects of the adapted muscle activity carry over to post-adaptation, when the split-belt perturbation has been removed. This novel analysis is promising because it allows us to determine what aspects of learning can be maintained when walking off of the treadmill.

  

III. Broader impact.

 Importantly, the funds of this award enabled the training of three students from underrepresented groups in science and engineering. One of the students was recruited from the University of Turabo, a Hispanic-serving institution in Puerto Rico. As a result from her reserach enabled by this award, she participated in two conferences to present her work and was admitted into the graduate program in Bioengineering at Pitt, where she will pursue graduate education.
